item.title: KVM and Hosting
item.description:
ðŸ§¾ Working with KVM Virtual Machines and Creating Networks (NAT, Isolated, Bridged) + Hosting a Local Repository Server

KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) combined with libvirt and virt-manager provides a powerful and flexible virtualization platform for Linux users. One of the most important aspects of virtualization is networking â€” giving VMs internet, isolating them, or letting them behave like physical machines on your LAN.

This article explains:

  • How KVM networking works
  • How to create different network types
  • How to connect VMs to them
  • How to host a local repository server and register VMs with it

1. Understanding KVM/libvirt Networking

KVM uses libvirt to create and manage software-defined networks. These show up as virtual bridges (e.g., virbr0, virbr1, virbr3).

item.title: Virtual Machine Archlinux
item.description:
Quick prerequisites â€” check your hardware

Confirm your CPU supports hardware virtualization (Intel VT-x or AMD-V):

# prints nonzero if VT-x/AMD-V present
egrep -c '(vmx|svm)' /proc/cpuinfo
# or a human readable line
lscpu | grep -i Virtualization

If the first command prints 0, enter your BIOS/UEFI and enable virtualization. KVM needs those CPU flags to use hardware acceleration. ([ArchWiki][1])

2) Install the packages (KVM/QEMU + libvirt + virt-manager)

Run:

sudo pacman -Syu
sudo pacman -S qemu libvirt virt-manager virt-viewer edk2-ovmf dnsmasq vde2 bridge-utils openbsd-netcat
  • qemu â€” the VM userspace (with KVM acceleration).
  • libvirt â€” daemon + management API.
  • virt-manager â€” GUI to create/manage VMs (optional; you can use virt-install CLI).
  • virt-viewer â€” simple console viewer.
  • edk2-ovmf â€” UEFI firmware for VMs (UEFI/OVMF support).
  • dnsmasq, vde2, bridge-utils â€” networking helpers commonly used with libvirt. ([ArchWiki][2])

(If you prefer a minimal set, qemu libvirt virt-install is enough for headless installs; virt-manager is optional for GUI.)
